sols_html:
We will prove this by induction on \(n\).

First, for \(n=1\), since \(b_1=2\) we clearly have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 \leq b_1 \leq 2\end{aligned}\]

Now, let us assume that the statement is true up to \(n=m\), that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 \leq b_n \leq 2 \quad\text{ for } n=1, \dots, m\end{aligned}\]

and let us show that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 \leq b_{m+1} \leq 2\end{aligned}\]

By definition of the sequence \({ b_n }\) we have that

\[\begin{aligned} b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m+\sqrt{b_m}}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Since \(b_m\) \(\leq\) 2 we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \sqrt{b_m} \leq \sqrt{2} \leq 2\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m + \sqrt{b_m}}{2} \leq \frac{2+2}{2} = 2\end{aligned}\]

And since \(b_m\) \(\geq\) 1 we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \sqrt{b_m} \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_{m+1} = \frac{b_m + \sqrt{b_m}}{2} \geq \frac{1+1}{2} = 1\end{aligned}\]

These two arguments show that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1 \leq b_{m+1} \leq 2\end{aligned}\]

and hence conclude our proof.

statement_html:
Let \(\{ b_n \}\) be a sequence defined by

\[\begin{aligned} b_1 =2 \quad \text{ and } \quad b_{n+1}=\frac{b_n + \sqrt{b_n}}{2} \quad\text{ for each }n \in \mathbb{N}.\end{aligned}\]

Prove that

\[\begin{aligned} 1 \leq b_n \leq 2 \quad\text{ for all } n \in \mathbb{N}.\end{aligned}\]
